list_page_teaser: Sam and Diane's turbulent relationship was in the forefront of the first five seasons of this classic sit-com.  Click to learn more!
description_html:
The turbulent relationship between Sam Malone and Diane Chambers on Cheers forms the basis for much of what goes on during the first five seasons of the sitcom. Their relationship is so well-known there is even a wikipedia page for the couple!

Sam and Diane not only have very different backgrounds, they have very different temperaments. The Yellow and Green in Sam's spiritual portrait shows he is more down-to-earth and logical, while the Blue and Red in Diane's image shows she prefers learning new ideas and expressing her emotions. Click on one or both images to see a larger version and learn more!
story_html:
When I first started writing the stories for Leia Organa and Han Solo — characters from the Original Star Wars trilogy — on this site, the term Sam and Diane popped into my head, suddenly and totally unbidden. I was somewhat surprised to see a whole page in the Wikipedia devoted to their relationship, and after some thought decided to re-watch all eleven seasons (271 episodes) of the show.

Although I'd seen most of them long ago, it was nice to watch them all again. And re-watcing all of them systematically filled in a few gaps — plot points and even entire shows that I'd either forgotten about or missed somehow.

The results appear here and in the other Cheers galleries. I hope you enjoy the images and stories!

To learn when I post new images and stories, follow this site on social media or join the SeeOurMinds.com email list!

image_list.title: Sam Malone
image_list.subtitle_html: Owner of Cheers, a Bar in Boston
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Sam Malone's spiritual portrait shows he is down-to-earth and reasonable.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Sam's dominant personality trait, his realism.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  He demonstrates this trait in the way he prefers sports and women to academic and intellectual pursuits.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Sam's auxiliary personality trait, his ability to (usually) keep a cool head.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrates this trait in the way he helps to smooth things over when people get upset.  In fact, only John Allen Hill, who owns Melville's, and of course Diane, can make Sam lose his cool.
image_list.story_intro_html: Sam Malone's spiritual portrait is colorful, indicating he can adapt to many situations, but it is predom....
image_list.story_html:
Sam Malone's spiritual portrait is colorful, indicating he can adapt to many situations, but it is predominantely Yellow and Green, indicating that in general he is realistic and reasonable.

Looking for New Experiences

In Sam's case, the Yellow represents his need for sensual stimulation. As a handsome, virule, sports figure, Sam frequently finds the stimulation he needs by seducing women, and he finds young, pretty women to be particularly alluring.

Just as Diane seems to have difficulty settling on a specific course of study, Sam has difficulty deciding on a specific woman:

Rebecca Howe: [to Sam] What do you say when you break up with a woman?
Sam Malone: I usually say, 'I'll call you tomorrow'.
 — From A Diminished Rebecca With a Suspended Cliff, 1992.

Today that's called ghosting, and it might sound harsh, but then compared to King Henry the Eighth, Sam's a real sweetheart.

Opposites Attract?

Sam and Diane share a tendency to be indecisive, and it's possible that without this indecisiveness, they may not have been open to sharing a relationship in the first place. Digging a little deeper, it's apparent they have opposing interests.

That Sam and Diane are opposites, at least in some respects, is obvious. In the episode Teacher's Pet, Sam admits his brain doesn't work like Diane's, because he can't learn things.

These opposing interests may contribute to the powerful attraction they feel — at least at first. Inevitably though, after the initial passion they feel wears off, they find the things they are interested in are entirely different. So when they try to spend a significant amount of time together, disaster, and hilarity, ensues.

Tell Me More! No Wait, Just Kidding, Please Don't!

After some ups-and-downs that are both entertaining and heartbreaking, Diane convinces Sam to go with her to see a counselor. They agree to see a friend of Frasier Crane's, the internationally famous Dr. Simon Finch-Royce, who is visiting Boston to receive an honorary degree.

Finch-Royce is played by the inimitable John Cleese, one of the original members of the Monty Python troup. He does not tell Sam and Diane what they want to hear:

Dr. Simon Finch-Royce: Well first of all and most obviously, you have absolutely nothing in common. On top of that you have an appalling lack of of communication.
Diane: What about the idea that opposites attract?
Simon: Ahh, the song of the truly desperate. Well take it from one who has observed dozens of failed marriages, the only thing that opposites attract is divorce.
Sam: Well wait, don't go, what should we do?
Simon: Well, think yourselves lucky, you've found out now, saved yourself years, perhaps decades of pain and heartache.
 — From Simon Says, 1987.

John Cleese won a Primetime Emmy for his performance, one of nine Primetime Emmys the series won during the eleven seasons it ran.

Diane Disappears, and Returns

After five years as a regular character on the show, Diane bid the show Adieu, only to return just before the series ends, when she and Sam give it one more try. Deciding whether it should work, and learning whether it does work, is left as an exercise for the reader.

People with opposing temperaments can build strong relationships and powerful teams, but conflict is inevitable. Although fictional relationships such as Sam and Diane's can give us insight into our own relationships, it's important to realize that everyone is different and all relationships have their own dynamics.

Most importantly, being able to visualize these preferences can help us understand others, learn to embrace their preferences — just as we learn to embrace our own idiosyncrasies — and enable us to live and work better together.

image_list.title: Diane Chambers
image_list.subtitle_html: Waitress at Cheers
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Diane Chambers's spiritual portrait shows she is very open to learning new things, especially new ideas.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Diane's dominant personality trait, her openness to ideas.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  She demonstrates this trait in the way she is enjoys taking a wide variety of classes, even at the post-graduate level.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Diane's auxiliary personality trait, her passion and compassion.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  She demonstrates this trait in way she is passionate about her studies and when she shows compassion for other people, even those who, like Carla, clearly do not like her.
image_list.story_intro_html: Diane Chambers's spiritual portrait is a sea of Blue, indicating she greatly prefers ....
image_list.story_html:
Diane Chambers's spiritual portrait is a sea of Blue, indicating she greatly prefers ideas to facts, and has some islands of Red, indicating she is more emotional than logical.

Looking for New Ideas

In Diane's case, the Blue represents her need for intellectual stimulation. As an intelligent, curious, well-bred woman, Diane frequently finds the stimulation she needs by learning new things, and she finds academic ideas to be particularly interesting.

Just as Sam seems to have difficulty settling on a specific woman, Diane has difficulty deciding on a specific course of study:

Sam: How did you know that?
Diane: Well I picked it up in pre-law.
Sam: I thought you were an English major.
Diane: Well that was after art and before psychology.
Sam: Is there anything you weren't in college?
Carla: Blonde.
Diane: Check the yearbook, Carla.
 — From The Tortelli Tort, 1982.

Diane has many interests, but few of them are very practical, and she has difficulty seeing things through. So even though she's smart, she's stuck in the same place as Carla, working as a waitress.

Opposites Attract?

Diane and Sam share a tendency to be indecisive, and it's possible that without this indecisiveness, they may not have been open to sharing a relationship in the first place. Digging a little deeper, it's apparent they have opposing interests.

That Diane and Sam are opposites, at least in some respects, is obvious. In the episode Diane Chambers Day, Diane admits she felt like an alien when she first walked into this place four years ago, and she continues to feel that way.

These opposing interests may contribute to the powerful attraction they feel — at least at first. Inevitably though, after the initial passion they feel wears off, they find the things they are interested in are entirely different. So when they try to spend a significant amount of time together, disaster, and hilarity, ensues.

Tell Me More! No Wait, Don't!

After some ups-and-downs that are both entertaining and heartbreaking, Diane convinces Sam to go with her to see a counselor. They agree to see a friend of Frasier Crane's, the internationally famous Dr. Simon Finch-Royce, who is visiting Boston to receive an honorary degree.

Finch-Royce is played by the inimitable John Cleese, one of the original members of the Monty Python troup. He does not tell Diane and Sam what they want to hear:

Dr. Simon Finch-Royce: Well first of all and most obviously, you have absolutely nothing in common. On top of that you have an appalling lack of of communication.
Diane: What about the idea that opposites attract?
Simon: Ahh, the song of the truly desperate. Well take it from one who has observed dozens of failed marriages, the only thing that opposites attract is divorce.
Sam: Well wait, don't go, what should we do?
Simon: Well, think yourselves lucky, you've found out now, saved yourself years, perhaps decades of pain and heartache.
 — From Simon Says, 1987.

John Cleese won a Primetime Emmy for this performance, one of nine Primetime Emmys the series won during the eleven seasons it ran.

Diane Disappears, and Returns

After five years as a regular character on the show, Diane bid the show Adieu, only to return just before the series ends, when she and Sam give it one more try. Deciding whether it should work, and learning whether it does work, is left as an exercise for the reader.

People with opposing temperaments can build strong relationships and powerful teams, but conflict is inevitable. Although fictional relationships such as Sam and Diane's can give us insight into our own relationships, it's important to realize that everyone is different and all relationships have their own dynamics.

Most importantly, being able to visualize these preferences can help us understand others, learn to embrace their preferences — just as we learn to embrace our own idiosyncrasies — and enable us to live and work better together.
